easyJet leads grilling of air traffic control after week of chaos
easyJet leads grilling of air traffic control after week of chaos
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
September 4, 2023 Monday 10:52 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 551 words
Byline: Josh Lamb
Body
easyJet PLC and Ryanair Holdings PLC (LSE:RYA) have asked questions of Britain's air traffic control systems 
after an hours-long failure last week sent the industry into chaos.
Airlines have effectively been left in the dark following the failure, which affected around 300,000 people and 
caused the cancellations of several thousand flights, the budget duo said.
"An incident of this scale should not have happened and must not happen again in the future," easyJet boss Johan 
Lundgren commented.
Ryanair said the failure "has still not been explained" meanwhile, as the Irish carrier revealed some 63,000 of its 
passengers were affected and 350 flights cancelled as a result.
According to National Air Traffic Services (NATS), its entire system went into shutdown on Monday for several 
hours due to some incorrect incoming data.
This left air traffic controllers having to manually input flight data, leading to a restriction being placed on the number 
of in and outgoing UK flights that could be handled.
Lundgren argued that "passengers deserve to see a full independent review" of the event, with this already 
promised to regulator the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) by NATS last week.
easyJet leads grilling of air traffic control after week of chaos
"[This should] not only result in meaningful improvements to prevent an incident of this scale happening again but 
also consider a wide range of issues beyond this incident," Lundgren said, "including staffing levels required at 
NATS to deliver today's flying and what modernisation is needed."
Over a quarter of Britain's flights are estimated to have been cancelled last Monday due to the fault, with thousands 
more delayed and issues continuing late into the week.
Most chaos-hit passengers had reached their final destinated come Saturday, according to transport secretary Mark 
Harper, with the review having been expected on Sunday.
How did it happen?
NATS first publicly notified that it was experiencing an issue at 12:10 British summer time (BST) on Monday 
afternoon.
"We are currently experiencing a technical issue and have applied traffic flow restrictions to maintain safety. 
Engineers are working to find and fix the fault," NATS reported initially.
Issues then continued into the afternoon, with another blog post at 12:40 BST reassuring that the air traffic 
controller was still working "hard to resolve the technical issue".
"To clarify, UK airspace is not closed, we have had to apply air traffic flow restrictions which ensures we can 
maintain safety," NATS then added.
An update at 14:20 then confirmed air traffic controllers had taken to manually inputting flight data, prompting the 
traffic restrictions given the more painstaking process.
Airlines such as easyJet, Ryanair and British Airways then warned of "severe" disruption, acknowledging flights 
would have to be cancelled.
At 15:15, just over three hours after the issue was first reported, NATS updated that the fault had been "identified 
and remedied".
Though seemingly just hours long, the fault had already ensured disruption for thousands of flights and the 
hundreds of passengers due to travel on each flight.
Given its severity, the industry has since called for answers to show such an issue could happen and who should 
bear the costs, with this tipped by the International Air Transport Association to be much as £100 million for the 
airlines affected.
Load-Date: September 4, 2023
End of Document
Airlines' ancillary costs face scrutiny in government consultation
Airlines' ancillary costs face scrutiny in government consultation
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
September 4, 2023 Monday 02:34 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 354 words
Byline: Josh Lamb
Body
Airlines' practice of hitting passengers with add-ons at the booking stage is facing public scrutiny through a 
government consultation.
Government research found that ancillary costs across a range of industries, including extra charges for specific 
seats or additional bags on flights, cost consumers £1.6 billion a year.
Given costs are often not advertised in the original price of flights, making them look cheaper at first glance, the 
consultation will seek ways to clamp down on the practice.
The Department for Business and Trade consultation will last six weeks from Monday, covering a range of 
industries, including the aviation sector.
"Fake reviews and hidden fees can make choices increasingly confusing and leaves customers unsure about what 
product is right for them," business minister Kevin Hollinrake commented.
Airlines generated some £81 billion through ancillary costs last year, in stark contrast with the £31 billion made 
through such add-ons in 2013.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (LSE:RYA) and easyJet PLC are among those to score significant proportions of revenue 
through these costs, with both seeing marked increases in their latest respective quarters.
Ancillary sales generated a total of (EURO)1.18 billion (£1.01 billion) for the Irish carrier during the first quarter-up 
15%-of total revenue worth (EURO)3.65 billion.
Airlines' ancillary costs face scrutiny in government consultation
easyJet marked a 28% increase in ancillary revenue in its latest quarterly results meanwhile, to £622 million, as 
passenger revenue climbed to £1.5 billion.
Per average passenger, Ryanair made (EURO)23.30 in ancillary revenue in the three months to June, while 
easyJet gained £23.75.
Though the costs range from priority boarding to food and drink on flights, reports have slated airlines for charging 
hefty prices for services such as printing ticket at airports.
The industry backed keeping such costs separate to ticket prices, arguing it allowed for better deals.
"Delivering value for consumers is at the heart of an airline business, with the competitiveness of the industry 
meaning it already delivers excellent choice, service and value to consumers," trade group Airlines UK commented.
Load-Date: September 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair and Wizz Air fly more passengers in August despite NATS outage
Ryanair and Wizz Air fly more passengers in August despite NATS outage
Alliance News UK
September 4, 2023 Monday 07:43 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 241 words
Body
(Alliance News) -  Budget airlines Ryanair Holdings PLC and Wizz Air Holdings PLC on Monday both said 
passenger traffic increased in August compared to a year before, with Wizz Air also seeing improved aircraft usage. 
Dublin-based Ryanair said that it carried 19 million passengers in August, up 11% from 17 million a year prior. The 
load factor was unchanged at 96%. 
On a rolling 12-month basis to August, Ryanair said it carried 177.4 million passengers, up 20% from 147.9 million 
a year before. The load factor improved to 94% from 89%. 
The Irish airline noted that 350 flights were cancelled between Monday and Tuesday last week due to an air traffic 
computer failure, which affected 63,000 passengers. Ryanair noted the computer failure still has not been explained 
by UK air traffic controller NATS.
Budapest-based Wizz Air said it carried 6.1 million passengers in August, representing a 24% compared to 5.0 
million passengers in August 2022, at a load factor of 94%, up from 91% a year ago. 
On a rolling 12-month basis, Wizz Air carried 56.6 million passengers, reflecting a 43% rise from 39.5 million a year 
before, at a load factor of 90%, up from 84%. 
Shares in Ryanair were down 1.1% at EUR16.05 each in Frankfurt on Monday morning, while Wizz Air shares were 
up 2.2% at 2,249.00 pence each. 
By Sabrina Penty, Alliance News reporter
Comments and questions to newsroom@alliancenews.com
Copyright 2023 Alliance News Ltd. All Rights Reserved.

September 4th, 2023 ( DailyPolitical  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Profund Advisors LLC lifted its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Free Report ) by 8.3% 
in the 1st quarter, HoldingsChannel  reports. The institutional investor owned 5,495 shares of the transportation 
company's stock after purchasing an additional 419 shares during the quarter. Profund Advisors LLC's holdings in 
Ryanair were worth $518,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Other hedge funds and other institutional investors also recently added to or reduced their stakes in the company. 
HighTower Advisors LLC raised its position in Ryanair by 10.3% during the 1st quarter. HighTower Advisors LLC 
now owns 3,047 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $265,000 after buying an additional 285 shares 
during the last quarter. Private Advisor Group LLC grew its position in Ryanair by 16.8% during the 1st quarter. 
Private Advisor Group LLC now owns 4,758 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $414,000 after 
purchasing an additional 683 shares during the period. Citigroup Inc. raised its stake in shares of Ryanair by 1.2% 
during the 1st quarter. Citigroup Inc. now owns 39,970 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$3,483,000 after buying an additional 483 shares during the last quarter. Bank of Montreal Can lifted its holdings in 
shares of Ryanair by 8.2% in the 1st quarter. Bank of Montreal Can now owns 11,691 shares of the transportation 
company's stock valued at $984,000 after buying an additional 884 shares during the period. Finally, Raymond 
James Trust N.A. boosted its stake in shares of Ryanair by 16.2% in the first quarter. Raymond James Trust N.A. 
now owns 3,406 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $297,000 after buying an additional 476 shares 
during the last quarter. Hedge funds and other institutional investors own 43.66% of the company's stock.
Wall Street Analyst Weigh In
Several brokerages recently weighed in on RYAAY. Raymond James lifted their price target on Ryanair from 
$135.00 to $140.00 and gave the company a "strong-buy" rating in a research report on Tuesday, July 25th. Royal 
Bank of Canada began coverage on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, June 27th. They set an "outperform" 
rating on the stock. Finally, StockNews.com  assumed coverage on shares of Ryanair in a research note on 
Thursday, August 17th. They set a "buy" rating on the stock. One research analyst has rated the stock with a hold 
rating, seven have issued a buy rating and one has assigned a strong buy rating to the company. According to data 
from MarketBeat, the stock currently has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of $59.00.

Ryanair Stock Performance
NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $98.04 on Monday. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.51, a current ratio of 
0.80 and a quick ratio of 0.80. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1-year low of $55.90 and a 1-year high of $112.75. The 
company has a market cap of $22.33 billion, a PE ratio of 12.09, a price-to-earnings-growth ratio of 0.61 and a beta 
of 1.45. The stock's 50 day simple moving average is $103.43 and its 200-day simple moving average is $99.64.

estimates of $2.25 by $0.90. Ryanair had a return on equity of 31.28% and a net margin of 14.96%. The company 
had revenue of $3.97 billion for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $3.59 billion. As a group, equities 
research analysts anticipate that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 9.06 EPS for the current fiscal year.
Ryanair Company Profile
( Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.

Ryanair reveals impact of UK air traffic chaos, but still enjoys record August
Ryanair reveals impact of UK air traffic chaos, but still enjoys record August
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
September 4, 2023 Monday 08:45 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 157 words
Byline: Ian Lyall
Body
Ryanair Holdings PLC (LSE:RYA) has revealed around 63,000 of its passengers had their flights cancelled due to 
last week's air traffic control failure.
This disruption, which left thousands stranded overseas, was caused by an issue with the National Air Traffic 
Services (Nats) processing flight plans automatically.
Despite these setbacks, the Irish carrier announced a record-breaking 11% increase in passengers for August 
compared to the same month last year. The airline transported 18.9 million passengers, surpassing its previous 
record set in July.
Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, criticised Nats for the disruption, describing it as "unacceptable" and 
demanding an explanation for the failure.
The disruption came at a particularly challenging time for the airline industry, with the end of the summer break for 
many schools leaving little spare capacity across the sector.
The shares, traded in Dublin, were up around 1% early on.

FTSE climbs on US cheer, up 3.6% in two-week rally
FTSE climbs on US cheer, up 3.6% in two-week rally
Citywire
September 4, 2023 Monday 9:29 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 483 words
Byline: Michelle McGagh
Highlight: The positive after-effects from Friday’s US jobs figures linger with the FTSE 100 continuing to rally on 
hopes of an end to interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve.
Body
The FTSE 100 has jumped another 0.7% on excitement that last Friday’s US jobs figures could mean an end to 
interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve.  
The UK blue-chip index gained 56 points to 7,520, extending a two-week rally that has seen the benchmark 
advance 3.6%, nearly eliminating its losses for the year which in capital terms stand at 0.4%. 
Susannah Streeter, head of markets at Hargreaves Lansdown, said markets enjoyed a ‘dose of Monday motivation, 
as investors assess the slightly sunnier prospects for the world economy’. 
‘Hopes have lifted that the US Federal Reserve’s efforts in taming unruly inflation in the US are working and not 
much more interest rate stick will be needed,’ Streeter said. 
‘There is also relief that Chinese efforts in stimulating demand might finally be paying off.’ 
Job numbers from the US on Friday showed the tightness in the jobs market was easing and the US is still 
considered resilient enough to avoid a recession. There is now an expectation that rates will be kept on hold at the 
upcoming Fed meeting and may now be unchanged for the rest of the year. 
Oil prices rose thanks to more upbeat manufacturing in China and the expectations of a continued squeeze in 
supply from Opec countries. Brent crude is now hovering around $88 a barrel. 
Glencore (GLEN) jumped to the top of the index, up 1.9%, or 8p, at 435p, followed by: 
•
Rio Tinto (RIO) up 1.6%, or 80p, at £50.55.
•
Anglo American (AAL) up 1.4%, or 30p, at £21.66.
•
BP (BP) up 1.1%, or 5p, at 506p.
•
Weir (WEIR) up 1%, or 18p, at £18.60.
Victoria Scholar, head of investment at Interactive Investor, said China-sensitive stocks like Glencore, Rio Tinto, 
and Anglo American also benefited from overnight gains in Asia that saw Hong Kong’s Hang Seng leap 2.5%. 
FTSE climbs on US cheer, up 3.6% in two-week rally
‘The Hang Seng rallied sharply after China reduced borrowing requirements for homebuyers in a bid to shore up its 
embattled real estate sector,’ Scholar said. 
‘Chinese property developer Country Garden shares surged after its creditors agreed to restructure some of its 
overdue debts, helping the business to avoid a default.’ 
In London, travel stocks rose as mid-cap Wizz Air (WIZZ) and Ryanair (RYA) reported passenger increases in 
August. The budget airline carrier flew 18.9m passengers, up from July’s record of 18.7m and 11% more than in 
August 2022. 
FTSE constituent and British Airways owner International Consolidated Airlines (IAG) gained 1.7%, or 2p, to 
162p. 
The FTSE 250 put on 0.4%, or 74 points, to 18,610, taking its advance since 21 August to 3.8%. Year to date, 
excluding dividends from companies, the index is still down 2.7% in price terms. 
Wizz Air added 2.1%, or 28p, at £22.48, with package holiday operator Tui (TUI) up 1.7%, or 8p, at 461p, while 
Easyjet (EZJ) added 1.7%, or 7p, to trade at 432p. 
BlackRock World Mining (BRWM ) investment trust rose 2.2%, or 13p, to 605p on the optimism for commodities 
consumption.
Load-Date: September 4, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair 's August Passenger Traffic Up 11%
Ryanair's August Passenger Traffic Up 11%
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 4, 2023 Monday 5:07 AM EST
Copyright 2023 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 38 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYA.IR) said Monday it carried 18.9 million passengers in August, up 11% year over year.
The budget airline's load factor for the month was unchanged year over year at 96%.
Shares gained 1% in midmorning trade.

Ryanair August Passenger Traffic, Load Factor Rise
Ryanair August Passenger Traffic, Load Factor Rise
RTT News (United States)
September 4, 2023 Monday
Copyright 2023 Content Engine, LLC.
All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2023 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 104 words
Byline: editorial@rttnews.com,  (RTT Staff Writer)
Body
       Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) reported Monday that its passenger traffic for the month of August grew 11 percent 
to 18.9 million guests from last year's 16.9 million guests.
 Load factor for the period was 96 percent, same as last year.
 For the rolling 12 month period, passenger traffic was up 20 percent from last year to 177.4 million guests, and 
load factor grew 5 percentage points to 94 percent.
 Ryanair operated over 103,000 flights in August 2023. The company noted that over 350 flights or 63,000 guests 
were cancelled on 28th/29th Aug due to NATS ATC computer "failure" which has still not been explained.        
Load-Date: September 5, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings ( RYAAY ) Passenger Traffic Swells in August
Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) Passenger Traffic Swells in August
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
September 4, 2023 Monday 3:31 PM EST
Delivered by Newstex LLC. All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2023 Zacks Investment Research
Length: 801 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Sep 04, 2023( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  
 Ryanair Holdings RYAAY[1] reported highly impressive traffic numbers for the month of August, driven by upbeat 
air travel demand. The number of passengers ferried on RYAAY flights in August was 18.9 million, implying that 
12% more passengers flew than a year ago. 
Owing to upbeat traffic, the load factor (percentage of seats filled by passengers) was as high as 96% in August. 
This, however, remained flat from its year-ago figure. 
Owing to buoyant air travel demand, shares of Ryanair have gained 34.7% over the past year compared with the 
12.1% growth of the Zacks Airline [2]industry. 
Image Source: Zacks Investment Research 
Ryanair has been benefiting from a stronger-than-expected recovery in air travel demand from the pandemic lows. 
While passenger volumes continue to be strong, what is all the more encouraging is the strong bounce back of 
international travel. 
Ryanair expects its traffic for fiscal 2024 to be 183.5 million. In spite of upbeat passenger volumes, RYAAY 
continues to be hurt due to headwinds like air traffic control strikes and further probable Boeing delivery delays. Due 
to the challenges, management trimmed its fiscal 2024 traffic forecast from 185 million. Zacks Rank & Key Picks 
Ryanair currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). 
Some better-ranked stocks for investors interested in the Zacks Transportation[3] sector are GATX Corporation 
GATX[4] and Triton International Limited TRTN[5]. 
GATX, which presently carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy), has strengthened its railcar leasing operations. You can see 
the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here[6]. 
For third-quarter and full-year 2023, GATX's earnings are expected to register 36.6% and 14.3% growth, 
respectively, on a year-over-year basis. 
Triton, which currently carries a Zacks Rank #2, is benefiting from its consistent efforts to reward shareholders 
through dividends and share repurchases. 
Triton has an impressive liquidity position. Its current ratio (a measure of liquidity) was 3.83 at the end of second-
quarter 2023. A current ratio of more than 1 often indicates that the company will be easily paying off its short-term 
obligations.

are well off their recent highs, you can expect big profits from the companies that supply the world with "black gold."

by Analysts
American Banking and Market News
September 3, 2023 Sunday
Copyright 2023 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 750 words
Body
Ryanair logo Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) have received a consensus 
recommendation of "Buy" from the eight ratings firms that are  covering the stock, Marketbeat  reports. One analyst  
has rated the stock with a hold rating, six have given a buy rating and one  has assigned  a strong buy rating to  the 
company. The average twelve-month price target among brokers that have issued a report on the stock in the last 
year is $123.55.  
A number of research analysts recently weighed in on the stock. Raymond James raised their price target on 
shares of Ryanair from $135.00 to $140.00 and gave the company a "strong-buy" rating in a research report on 
Tuesday, July 25th. StockNews.com  assumed coverage on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Thursday, 
August 17th. They set a "buy" rating on the stock. Finally, Royal Bank of Canada began coverage on shares of 
Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, June 27th. They set an "outperform" rating on the stock. 
Read Our Latest Analysis on Ryanair Ryanair Stock Down 1.2 %
Ryanair stock  opened at $98.04 on Friday. Ryanair has a 1-year low of $55.90 and a 1-year high of $112.75. The 
firm has a market capitalization of $22.33 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 12.09, a price-to-earnings-growth ratio 
of 0.61 and a beta of 1.45. The firm's fifty day moving average price is $103.43 and its two-hundred day moving 
average price is $99.61. The company has a current ratio of 0.80, a quick ratio of 0.80 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 
0.51.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last released its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 24th. 
The transportation company reported $3.15 earnings per share for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus 
estimates of $2.25 by $0.90. Ryanair had a net margin of 14.96% and a return on equity of 31.28%. The company 
had revenue of $3.97 billion for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $3.59 billion.  On average, equities 
research analysts predict that  Ryanair will post 9.11 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  Hedge Funds

Envestnet Asset Management Inc. increased its holdings in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - 
Free Report ) by 455.5% in the first quarter, according to the company in its most recent filing with the Securities 
and Exchange Commission (SEC). The firm owned 787,371 shares of the transportation company's stock after 
purchasing an additional 645,627 shares during the period. Envestnet Asset Management Inc. owned 0.35% of 
Ryanair worth $15,836,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.

purchased a new position in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at about $41,000. International Assets 
Investment Management LLC purchased a new position in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter valued at about 
$46,000. Belpointe Asset Management LLC purchased a new position in shares of Ryanair in the 4th quarter valued 
at about $45,000. Zions Bancorporation N.A. increased its holdings in shares of Ryanair by 26.0% in the 1st 
quarter. Zions Bancorporation N.A. now owns 1,900 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$166,000 after purchasing an additional 392 shares in the last quarter. Finally, Captrust Financial Advisors 
increased its holdings in Ryanair by 25.9% during the 2nd quarter. Captrust Financial Advisors now owns 1,963 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $132,000 after acquiring an additional 404 shares in the last 
quarter. Institutional investors and hedge funds own 43.66% of the company's stock.
Ryanair Trading Down 1.2 %
RYAAY  opened at $98.04 on Friday. The firm has a market capitalization of $22.33 billion, a P/E ratio of 12.09, a 
P/E/G ratio of 0.61 and a beta of 1.45. The firm's 50 day moving average is $103.43 and its 200-day moving 
average is $99.61. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52-week low of $55.90 and a 52-week high of $112.75. The 
company has a quick ratio of 0.80, a current ratio of 0.80 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.51.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The 
transportation company reported $3.15 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus 
estimates of $2.25 by $0.90. The business had revenue of $3.97 billion during the quarter, compared to analyst 
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Acquired by Envestnet Asset Management Inc.
estimates of $3.59 billion. Ryanair had a net margin of 14.96% and a return on equity of 31.28%. Analysts expect 
that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 9.11 EPS for the current fiscal year.

RYAAY has been the subject of several recent research reports. StockNews.com  initiated coverage on shares of 
Ryanair in a report on Thursday, August 17th. They set a "buy" rating for the company. Raymond James raised 
their price target on shares of Ryanair from $135.00 to $140.00 and gave the stock a "strong-buy" rating in a

price of $59.00.

About Ryanair
( Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.

Ryanair Stock Performance
Shares of NASDAQ RYAAY  opened at $98.04 on Friday. Ryanair has a 12-month low of $55.90 and a 12-month 
high of $112.75. The company has a market cap of $22.33 billion, a PE ratio of 12.09, a P/E/G ratio of 0.61 and a 
beta of 1.45. The stock has a 50 day simple moving average of $103.43 and a 200-day simple moving average of 
$99.61. The company has a current ratio of 0.80, a quick ratio of 0.80 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.51.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last announced its earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The 
transportation company reported $3.15 EPS for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of $2.25 by $0.90. 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 31.28% and a net margin of 14.96%. The firm had revenue of $3.97 billion for the 
quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $3.59 billion. On average, equities research analysts forecast that 
Ryanair will post 9.11 EPS for the current year.

transportation company's stock worth $320,000 after buying an additional 129 shares during the last quarter. 
Institutional investors and hedge funds own 43.66% of the company's stock.
Ryanair Company Profile
( Get Free Report
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.

Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Shares Gap Up to $98.82
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Gap Up to $98.82
Newstex Blogs 
Transcript Daily
September 2, 2023 Saturday 9:46 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 645 words
Body
September 2nd, 2023 ( Transcript Daily  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report )'s stock price gapped up before the market opened on 
Thursday . The stock had previously closed at $98.82, but opened at $101.03. Ryanair shares last traded at 
$100.37, with a volume of 73,391 shares traded.
Wall Street Analysts Forecast Growth
A number of brokerages recently commented on RYAAY. Royal Bank of Canada assumed coverage on shares of 
Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, June 27th. They set an "outperform" rating for the company. Raymond James lifted 
their price objective on Ryanair from $135.00 to $140.00 and gave the stock a "strong-buy" rating in a research 
report on Tuesday, July 25th. Finally, StockNews.com  started coverage on Ryanair in a research note on 
Thursday, August 17th. They issued a "buy" rating on the stock. One analyst has rated the stock with a hold rating, 
seven have assigned a buy rating and one has issued a strong buy rating to the company's stock. Based on data 
from MarketBeat.com, Ryanair presently has a consensus rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of $59.00.
Read Our Latest Research Report on Ryanair
Ryanair Price Performance
The stock has a market capitalization of $22.33 billion, a PE ratio of 12.09, a PEG ratio of 0.61 and a beta of 1.44. 
The company's 50 day simple moving average is $103.43 and its 200 day simple moving average is $99.59. The 
company has a current ratio of 0.80, a quick ratio of 0.80 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.51.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last released its earnings results on Monday, July 24th. The 
transportation company reported $3.15 EPS for the quarter, beating the consensus estimate of $2.25 by $0.90. 
Ryanair had a return on equity of 31.28% and a net margin of 14.96%. The firm had revenue of $3.97 billion during 
the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $3.59 billion. On average, equities analysts anticipate that Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post 9.11 earnings per share for the current year.

About Ryanair
( Get Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and 
mobile app.

Ryanair Group faces 737 Max delivery delays
Ryanair Group faces 737 Max delivery delays
AirFinance Journal
September 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 231 words
Byline: Hugh Davies
Body
Ryanair has said ongoing production delays will leave the company 13 Boeing 737 Max aircraft deliveries short of 
the expected 27 aircraft expected ahead of this year's winter season.
The delays, which may extend into 2024, will push the company to cut winter capacity across Europe as it has no 
spare aircraft due to scheduled maintenance necessary across the fleet to be ready for summer 2024.
Ryanair said it is working with Boeing to try to accelerate deliveries so that it can enter the summer 2024 period with 
all 57 new Boeing aircraft deliveries as expected by May 2024.
"We are working closely with Boeing and their supplier, Spirit, to minimise these delivery delays. It is deeply 
regrettable that production problems in Wichita, and in Seattle, have yet again delayed Boeing's contracted 
deliveries to Ryanair this winter," commented Ryanair Group chief executive officer Michael O'Leary.
"We are in regular dialogue with Boeing, and our primary objective is to ensure we get delivery of all 57 contracted 
B737 aircraft before the end of May 2024, so that Ryanair's fleet can grow to over 600 aircraft for what will be our 
largest ever summer flight programme."
Ryanair said these delivery delays will not impact its full-year traffic guidance of 183.5 million passengers, however 
if the delays worsen or extend further into the first quarter, it may have to adjust "slightly downward".
Load-Date: October 16, 2023
End of Document
Boeing sees busy month for lessor orders
Boeing sees busy month for lessor orders
AirFinance Journal
September 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 230 words
Byline: Hugh Davies
Body
Boeing registered 35 deliveries in August, down from 43 units in July, and the same number as in August last year.
It was also the slowest delivery month for Boeing since April, according to the data.
Year-to-date deliveries for the US manufacturer now stand at 344 aircraft, including 271 Boeing 737 Max aircraft.
The 737 Max made up 22 of last month's deliveries, with seven units for Southwest Airlines, five for United Airlines, 
two for American Airlines and one each for Gol Linhas Aereas, Ryanair and Alaska Airlines.
Five 787 family aircraft were delivered, including a 787-8 for Japan Airlines.
Boeing also delivered three 777 freighters, two for Fedex and one unit going to China Airlines.
Lessors accounted for only four direct deliveries last month, with three 737 Max aircraft handed over to Aercap and 
one to BOC Aviation.
However, August's order activity was dominated by lessors, with Aviation Capital Group and SMBC Aviation Capital 
making up all 38 of the total 737 Max orders placed last month.
The SMBC AC order was confirmed this week, bringing lessor 737 Max orders to 1,300 units.
Another seven 787-family aircraft were ordered by undisclosed customers, bring gross orders to 45 units in August.
Boeing's 737 Max unfilled order list consists of 2,776 737 Max 8s, 336 737 Max 8-200s and 131 737 Max 9s, with 
297 and 813 yet-to-enter service 737 Max 7s and 10s respectively.
Load-Date: October 2, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair appoints Grabowski to its board
Ryanair appoints Grabowski to its board
AirFinance Journal
September 2023
Copyright 2023 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 180 words
Byline: Olivier Bonnassies
Body
The board of Ryanair Holdings has appointed Bertrand Grabowski as a non-executive director effective from 1 
October, 2023.
Grabowski will also join Ryanair's audit committee.
He has almost 40 years aviation and transport finance experience. A former executive board member of DVB Bank 
SE, he previously held senior roles with Citibank, Credit Agricole Indosuez and Banque Indosuez and is currently 
an independent aviation consultant. Grabowski is also a non-executive director of Jazeera Airways, a publicly listed 
company on the Kuwait stock exchange.
Ryanair's chairman Stan McCarthy commented: "We are pleased that Bertrand Grabowski has accepted our 
invitation to join the Board of Ryanair Holdings plc from 1 Oct. 2023. Bertrand has considerable experience and 
skills in the field of aviation finance, coupled with a detailed knowledge of global aviation, and will, we believe, make 
a significant contribution to both our Board and our Audit Committee. We look forward to working with him to 
achieve Ryanair's exciting and ambitious goals over the coming decade of Ryanair growth."
Load-Date: October 16, 2023
End of Document

August 31st, 2023 ( Ticker Report  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) shares gapped up before the market opened on 
Thursday . The stock had previously closed at $98.82, but opened at $101.03. Ryanair shares last traded at 
$100.37, with a volume of 73,391 shares traded.
Analysts Set New Price Targets
A number of research analysts recently commented on RYAAY shares. StockNews.com  assumed coverage on 
shares of Ryanair in a research note on Thursday, August 17th. They issued a "buy" rating on the stock. Royal 
Bank of Canada initiated coverage on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, June 27th. They issued an 
"outperform" rating on the stock. Finally, Raymond James raised their target price on Ryanair from $135.00 to 
$140.00 and gave the company a "strong-buy" rating in a report on Tuesday, July 25th. One analyst has rated the 
stock with a hold rating, seven have assigned a buy rating and one has issued a strong buy rating to the company. 
According to MarketBeat.com, the company currently has a consensus rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price 
of $59.00.
Read Our Latest Research Report on RYAAY
Ryanair Stock Performance
The company has a fifty day moving average price of $103.76 and a two-hundred day moving average price of 
$99.56. The company has a market capitalization of $22.61 billion, a P/E ratio of 12.18, a PEG ratio of 0.61 and a 
beta of 1.44. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.51, a current ratio of 0.80 and a quick ratio of 0.80.
Ryanair ( NASDAQ:RYAAY  - Get Free Report ) last announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 24th. 
The transportation company reported $3.15 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the consensus 
estimate of $2.25 by $0.90. Ryanair had a net margin of 14.96% and a return on equity of 31.28%. The firm had 
revenue of $3.97 billion during the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $3.59 billion. Equities analysts 
forecast that Ryanair Holdings plc will post 9.11 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.

( Get Free Report )
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and internationally. It is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, 
such as non-flight scheduled and Internet-related services, as well as in-flight sale of beverages, food, duty-free, 
and merchandise; and markets car hire, travel insurance, and accommodation services through its website and

Airlines losing millions as fingers pointed over air traffic control chaos
Airlines losing millions as fingers pointed over air traffic control chaos
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
August 30, 2023 Wednesday 11:29 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 561 words
Byline: Josh Lamb
Body
Monday's air traffic control system failure will likely be costing airlines millions of pounds, industry members have 
warned, as focus turns to the causes of the chaos.
After some 1,500 flights faced cancellations on Monday on the back of the National Air Traffic Services (Nats) 
system failure, carriers have faced pressure to act swiftly in helping the roughly 300,000 passengers affected.
Ryanair Holdings PLC (LSE:RYA) and easyJet PLC have since launched repatriation flights to rescue those strewn 
across Europe for instance, though two days after the issue, disruption continues.
 While there is still some disruption due to Monday's air traffic restrictions, most passengers will be able to travel as 
planned through Heathrow today. Passengers are reminded to check with their airline for the latest info about their 
flight. - Heathrow Airport (@HeathrowAirport) August 30, 2023
International Air Transport Association director general Willie Walsh warned on Wednesday that airlines have likely 
faced huge financial hits meanwhile, as questions build over how such a failure could happen.
"We're looking at costs in the tens of millions probably at this stage," he said on BBC Radio.
"[It's] too early to estimate fully, but I would imagine at an industry level we'll be getting close to £100 million of 
additional costs that airlines have encountered as a result."
Walsh also argued that Nats should be made to pay for the disruption, which ultimately saw air traffic controllers 
resort to inputting flight data manually for several hours on Monday.
Airlines losing millions as fingers pointed over air traffic control chaos
"The people responsible for the cancellations should bear the costs [...] this is a failure that shouldn't have 
happened," he added.
Consumer group Which? explained it was indeed the airlines that are responsible for ensuring passengers are kept 
up to date and accommodated if their flights are cancelled though.
"Airlines have a duty of care to passengers and are required to provide food and drink after two to three hours of 
delay," the consumer group said.
However, whether passengers are granted compensation is another matter, it warned.
"The air traffic control failure took place on 28 August," the group continued.
"Any disruption on that day and the following days will be classed as extraordinary circumstances, which means no 
compensation is due.
"However, if your flight several days or a week later is cancelled or delayed and the airline claims it's a result of the 
air traffic control system failure, you may be due compensation."
A report on the system failure is due from Nats to the UK regulator the Civil Aviation Authority "in the coming days", 
according to transport secretary Mark Harper.
Given speculation that it was incorrect information from a French airline that sent the system into shutdown and firm 
denial that the issue was caused by a cyberattack, the true cause remains to be seen.
 An update from our CEO, Martin Rolfe on yesterday's air traffic control outage that we know continues to impact 
passengers around the world. pic.twitter.com/GtLeNE6rKf - NATS (@NATS) August 29, 2023
"Airlines are clear about their responsibilities to passengers and are working with the rest of the industry to safely 
get them to their destinations," Harper added.
"The aviation minister Charlotte Vere and I are being kept up to date on the latest developments and will be 
reviewing the interim report from NATS."
Load-Date: August 30, 2023
End of Document
Flight chaos CAA to probe air traffic control failure
Flight chaos CAA to probe air traffic control failure
Financial Times (London, England)
August 30, 2023 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 2
Length: 466 words
Body
The aviation regulator is preparing to launch an investigation into the collapse of the air traffic control system at the 
end of a busy bank holiday weekend, as delays continued with around 300 flights cancelled yesterday.
The Civil Aviation Authority is in talks with the government about the scope of an inquiry into the failure at National 
Air Traffic Services on Monday, a person familiar with the discussions said.
More than a quarter of flights in and out of the UK were cancelled on Monday, and many more were delayed as a 
result of the failure.
Transport secretary Mark Harper said yesterday that the CAA would have to take "an independent look" given the 
scale of the problem. "A report will then come to me and we will look at that to see if there are lessons to be learned 
about reducing the risk of it happening again," he told ITV's Good Morning Britain.
The failure, which Nats blamed on a "technical issue", grounded hundreds of flights on one of the busiest days of 
the year as air traffic controllers had to input flight plans manually. Nats said yesterday it had launched a "thorough 
investigation", which it would share with the CAA and the government.
Harper said his priority was to make sure passengers "get where they need to be as quickly as possible". The 
government was ready to provide "further appropriate support" to airlines if required. Nats said its systems were 
"operating as normal" but airlines and airports were dealing with a backlog of passengers, leading to some 
cancellations.
Flight chaos CAA to probe air traffic control failure
Cirium, an aviation analytics group, said that based on early estimates about 5 per cent of flights had been 
cancelled, affecting 147 departures and 134 arrivals.
Despite the widespread disruption, passengers are unlikely to be able to claim compensation from airlines as the 
rules exempt "extraordinary circumstances", such as air traffic control system failures.
British Airways said it was still experiencing "knock-on effects". EasyJet said "some flights ... were, unfortunately, 
unable to operate".
Michael O'Leary, chief executive of Ryanair, said it was "not acceptable" that Nats had allowed its "computer 
systems to be taken down and everybody's flights get cancelled".
Willy Walsh, head of the International Air Transport Association, which represents the big airlines worldwide, 
criticised the CAA. "The failure of this essential service is unacceptable and brings into question the oversight of the 
CAA who are required to review the Nats resilience plan under the terms of its licence," he said.
"Airlines will bear significant sums in care and assistance charges, on top of the costs of disruption
But it will cost Nats nothing." Sylvia Pfeifer, Leke Oso Alabi and Jim Pickard
'The failure of this essential service is unacceptable and brings into question the oversight of the CAA'
Graphic
 
Passengers wait at Stansted airport yesterday as cancellations and delays continued following Monday's technical 
problems Daniel Leal/AFP/Getty Images
Load-Date: August 29, 2023

Ryanair Chief Calls Out Air Traffic Manager Over Monday's Technical Disruption
Ryanair Chief Calls Out Air Traffic Manager Over Monday's Technical 
Disruption
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
August 30, 2023 Wednesday 1:37 AM EST
Copyright 2023 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 99 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.IR) Chief Executive Officer Michael O'Leary said the UK's National Air Traffic Service, or NATS, 
should not have allowed their computer systems to be taken down in light of the technical disruption that caused 
hundreds of flight cancellations on Monday.
O'Leary said they are yet to receive an explanation from the air traffic controller regarding the cause and the 
absence of backup systems amid the disruption, City A.M. reported Tuesday.
On Monday, the Irish ultra-low-cost carrier canceled 250 flights and another 70 on Tuesday. 
Ryanair rose marginally when Tuesday's trading closed.

Online Travel Update: Hyatt 's Resort Fee Battle and Amazon 's Climb in the Travel Realm
Online Travel Update: Hyatt's Resort Fee Battle and Amazon's Climb in the 
Travel Realm
Newstex Blogs 
JD Supra
August 30, 2023 Wednesday 3:15 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 444 words
Byline: Foster Garvey PC
Body
August 30th, 2023 ( JD Supra  — Delivered by  Newstex )
This week's Update features a variety of stories, including the latest news on the new cottage industry of resort fee 
litigation and Amazon's growing (yet understated) significance in the travel industry. Enjoy.
Hyatt Faces Class Action Over Resort Fees. Late last week, consumer advocacy group, Travelers United, filed a 
class action in Washington D.C. superior court over Hyatt's alleged resort or destination fee practices. This lawsuit 
is the latest in a string of lawsuits brought against hoteliers (e.g., Hilton and Hyatt) and OTAs (Booking Holdings) 
over their alleged failure to properly disclose mandatory fees.
Amazon's Growing Understated Influence in the Travel Industry. Thought you knew everything about Amazon's 
pursuit of the travel industry? Think again. While many of us get caught up in Amazon's latest efforts in Indian rail 
passes or virtual tour offerings, Amazon has been quietly growing its role in the travel industry - largely through its 
cloud computing offering, Amazon Web Services. Amazon's cloud customers include Travelport, ATPCO, Lonely 
Planet, Ryanair and Trip.com. In fact, AWS and Trip.com have formed a joint innovation lab focused on, among 
other things, flight business, hotel business and artificial intelligence.

hotel company dealing with a fee-related lawsuit. Consumer advocacy group Travelers United filed a class action 
against Hyatt with the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, alleging that the hospitality company ...

extends the company's reach into the travel industry.

American Airlines is suing a travel website that sells tickets that let people save money by exploiting a quirk in 
airline pricing. American sued Skiplagged Inc. last week in federal court in Fort Worth, Texas, accusing the website 
of deception. It threatened to cancel every ticket that ...

Changing traveler behavior from 2020-2022 has brought about several noteworthy shifts, some of which are 
expected to endure for a considerable period, particularly related to travel distribution.

France calls for minimum price on European flights
France calls for minimum price on European flights
Newstex Blogs 
Digital Journal
August 30, 2023 Wednesday 6:01 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 209 words
Byline: AFP
Body
August 30th, 2023 ( Digital Journal  — Delivered by  Newstex )
France's transport minister called Wednesday for a minimum price for plane flights in Europe to battle climate 
change.
Transport Minister Clement Beaune said in an interview with the weekly L'Obs that he would submit such a 
proposal to his EU counterparts in the coming days.
"Plane tickets for 10 euros when we're in the midst of the ecological transition, that's no longer possible," Beaune 
told the magazine.
"That doesn't reflect the price for the planet," he added.
Low-cost airlines made major inroads in Europe by offering rock-bottom fares on some routes, with Ryanair 
becoming the region's largest airline.
But the low fares sometimes don't cover costs, and flying emits more greenhouse gases than travelling by train.
"I openly call for taxing polluting activities to invest in the ecological transition," said Beaune, adding that the 
government plans to increase the tax on flights departing France to fund rail investments.
Increased levies on companies managing France's highways and on airline tickets are likely figure in the 2024 
budget due to be unveiled at the end of September.
Low-cost airlines have also been a source of controversy in France over their wages and labour practices.

Zacks.com featured highlights include Medpace, Invitation Home and 
Ryanair
Newstex Blogs 
Zacks Investment Research
August 30, 2023 Wednesday 11:56 AM EST
Delivered by Newstex LLC. All Rights Reserved
Copyright 2023 Zacks Investment Research
Length: 1473 words
Byline: Zacks Equity Research
Body
Aug 30, 2023( Zacks Investment Research: http://www.zacks.com/ Delivered by Newstex) ; 
 For Immediate Release Chicago, IL - August 30, 2023 - Stocks in this week's article are Medpace Holdings, Inc. 
MEDP[1], Invitation Home Inc. INVH[2] and Ryanair Holdings plc RYAAY[3]. 3 Top Stocks Exhibiting Superb 
Earnings Growth Earnings growth is the main priority for any organization. This is because if the company doesn't 
make money, it won't last sooner or later. 
So, what's earnings growth? Study a company's revenues over a given period, subtract the production cost, and 
you have earnings. Incidentally, this is also considered the most important variable manipulating the share price. 
But, expectations of earnings play a significant role. Earnings Estimates & Share Price Movements Frequently, we 
have seen a decline in the stock price despite earnings growth and a rally in price following an earnings decline. 
This is largely the result of a company's earnings failing to meet market expectations. 
Earnings estimates embody analysts' opinions on factors such as sales growth, product demand, competitive 
industry environment, profit margins, and cost control. Thus, earnings estimates serve as a valuable tool, while 
making investment decisions. Earnings estimates also help analysts assess the cash flow to determine the fair 
value of a firm. 
Thus, investors should be on the lookout for stocks ready to make a big move. Hence, investors need to buy stocks 
with historical earnings growth and are seeing a rise in quarterly and annual earnings estimates. 
The above criteria narrowed down the universe of around 7,839 stocks to only six. Here are the top three stocks 
that stand out: 
Medpace Holdings, Inc. is a scientifically driven, global, full-service clinical contract research organization. Medpace 
has a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). MEDP's expected earnings growth rate for the current year is 15.3%. You can 
see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank stocks here[4]. 
Invitation Home Inc. provides real estate services. It focuses on owning, renovating, leasing and operating single-
family residential properties. Invitation Home has a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). INVH's expected earnings growth rate for 
the current year is 7.2%. 
Ryanair Holdings plc provides scheduled passenger airline services. Ryanair has a Zacks Rank #1. RYAAY's 
expected earnings growth rate for the current year is almost 25%.

Flight chaos to last for days after UK air traffic control fault
Flight chaos to last for days after UK air traffic control fault
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
August 29, 2023 Tuesday 09:45 AM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 292 words
Byline: Josh Lamb
Body
Disruption to flights in and out of the UK is set to last for days following an air traffic control technical fault on 
Monday.
After more than 1,500 flights were cancelled on Monday, transport secretary Mark Harper warned on BBC Radio 4 
that further disruption was expected.
"It is going to take some days to get completely everybody back to where they should be," he said.
"Airlines have a responsibility either to get people back on a flight to get them home or to pay for them to be 
accommodated and to sort out accommodation of them, and for food or drink as well."
A flight planning system technical fault saw National Air Traffic Services (Nats) forced to turn to manual operations 
on Monday, prompting delays and cancellations to flights to and from the UK.
Though Nats said the issue had been identified and fixed by Monday afternoon, several hours of controllers having 
to input flight data manually saw the likes of British Airways, easyJet, Tui and Ryanair all cancel flights.
"We are continuing to experience the knock-on effects of yesterday's Nats air traffic control issue, which includes 
unavoidable delays and cancellations," BA said on Tuesday.
Heathrow, which experienced the highest number of cancellations, also warned of further delays on Tuesday.
 Due to yesterday's technical issues suffered by UK Air Traffic Control, there may be some continuing disruption on 
some routes, including flight cancellations. (1/2) - Heathrow Airport (@HeathrowAirport) August 29, 2023
Flight chaos to last for days after UK air traffic control fault
"Schedules continue to be affected by yesterday's restrictions on UK airspace," an airport spokesperson 
commented.
"While the majority of passengers will still be able to travel, there will unfortunately be some disruption on some 
routes, including flight cancellations."
Load-Date: August 29, 2023
End of Document
Airlines under fire as travel chaos continues
Airlines under fire as travel chaos continues
 
Proactive Investors (UK)
August 29, 2023 Tuesday 03:03 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Proactive UK Ltd All Rights Reserved
Length: 385 words
Byline: Josh Lamb
Body
Some 300 flights have been cancelled on Tuesday, following the grounding of thousands on Monday due to an air 
traffic control fault, prompting criticism of airlines.
Though the National Air Traffic Services (Nats) failure, which forced controllers to turn to manually inputting flight 
data, was said to be fixed on Monday afternoon, disruption has continued.
Some 75 flights are said to have been cancelled at Gatwick, with 74 axed at Heathrow, alongside further flights at 
the likes of Manchester, Stansted, Luton and Edinburgh.
The cancellations are likely to have hit over 300,000 people, prompting huge pressure on airlines to accommodate 
and feed those affected.
Airlines should be "proactively" communicating with passengers and take "every possible step" to address the 
disruption, Downing Street said on Tuesday.
Individual accounts have suggested some stranded passengers have been offered little information about 
alternative flights as the chaos continues though.
Portia Oduba slated easyJet on Instagram after becoming stranded in Greece with her husband - television 
presenter Ore Oduba - and their children.
"easyJet have cancelled all flights leaving till Sunday," she said before the family booked an alternative flight
Airlines under fire as travel chaos continues
"But it's ok. They've offered us a voucher for the next time we fly. Maybe we can fly home on that, magic carpet 
style."
A spokesperson for prime minister Rishi Sunak reiterated that it seemed to be a technical fault that had affected the 
Nats system and not a cyber-attack.
Rumours have also circulated that an inputting error by a French airline could have sparked the system failure.
"There's going to be an investigation by the Civil Aviation Authority and a report shared with government [...] in 
days," the spokesperson added.
"It's not acceptable that UK Nats simply allow their computer systems to be taken down, and everybody's flights get 
cancelled or delayed," Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary said in a video posted on social media.
 Michael O'Leary, CEO of the Ryanair Group gives an update on delays/cancellations due to UK ATC failure on Aug 
28 pic.twitter.com/HoebuSNqBy - Ryanair (@Ryanair) August 29, 2023
According to O'Leary, the budget Irish carrier is among those having to cancel further flights on Tuesday, with 
misplaced planes and out-of-hours crews adding to issues.
Load-Date: August 29, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair Announces New Base Opening in Copenhagen
Ryanair Announces New Base Opening in Copenhagen
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
August 29, 2023
Copyright 2023 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News - Airports; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 337 words
Body
Ryanair has announced the upcoming launch of a new two-aircraft base in Copenhagen in December 2023. The 
new base will create up to 100 jobs for pilots, cabin crew and engineers as part of a US$200m new aircraft 
investment.
The Copenhagen base will be the second Ryanair base operating in Denmark, joining the airline's two-aircraft base 
in Billund, central Denmark.
"Ryanair is pleased to announce this two-aircraft base in Copenhagen from Dec, which will compliment our two-
aircraft base in Billund," said Michael O'Leary, CEO of Ryanair. "This represents a further $200m investment by 
Ryanair in the recovery of air traffic and tourism in Copenhagen, which continues to lag behind its pre-Covid 
volumes. Ryanair believes this is because the high airport fees and the high fares being charged by NAS and SAS, 
which hampers recovery of Danish traffic and tourism."
Ryanair expects to carry 184 million passengers in 2023/2024, up by 24% from pre-Covid traffic figures, which saw 
149 million passengers. The addition of the new base will offer passengers flying from Copenhagen low fares and 
more choice for early morning departures and late evening arrivals in Copenhagen.
"Ryanair's new Copenhagen base will build on our existing 20 routes, which we operate to/from Copenhagen on 
aircraft based outside Denmark," added O'Leary. "Today's announcement means that from Dec, these low fares will 
now extend to early morning departures and late evening arrivals and will provide much-needed choice and low fare 
competition to Denmark's State-aided, high-fare airlines SAS and NAS."

across the globe with our Advertising Multimedia Network, Advertising eMail: advert@AirGuideOnline.com and

new base will create up to 100 jobs for pilots, cabin crew and engineers as part of a US$200m new aircraft 
investment.

UK Orders Review Into Air Traffic Control Chaos
UK Orders Review Into Air Traffic Control Chaos
Newstex Blogs 
International Business Times News
August 29, 2023 Tuesday 4:21 PM EST
Copyright 2023 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 531 words
Byline: AFP News
Body
August 29th, 2023 ( International Business Times News  — Delivered by  Newstex )
Britain's government on Tuesday ordered a review after the country's air traffic control system suffered its worst 
disruption in almost 10 years, stranding thousands of passengers.
Flights departing and arriving in the UK continued to be cancelled, one day after air traffic control systems were 
temporarily hit by a technical fault.
Transport Secretary Mark Harper said there would be an independent review into the worst incident of its kind for 
"nearly a decade" that is expected to last well into the week.
"This was a technical fault. We do not think this was a cybersecurity incident," he told GB News.
The last Monday of August -- a public holiday in England, Wales and Northern Ireland -- traditionally sees large 
numbers of passengers returning from summer vacations.
"I know people will be enormously frustrated by the disruption that's impacting them," Prime Minister Rishi Sunak 
told British broadcasters.
"Thankfully things like this are rare and the issue itself was fixed in a matter of hours, but the disruption obviously is 
continuing and will last for a little while longer."
The National Air Traffic Services (NATS) said it "identified and remedied" a technical issue which forced it to impose 
traffic flow restrictions.
NATS said the issue meant flight plans had to be processed manually, while it indicated to AFP that hundreds of 
flights had been affected and that it would take "several days" for the situation to return to normal.
London's main airports were the worst hit, with Heathrow and Gatwick cancelling dozens of flights Tuesday.
British Airways was the worst affected airline.
UK Orders Review Into Air Traffic Control Chaos
Aviation analytics company Cirium said 790 departures and 785 arrivals were cancelled across all UK airports on 
Monday.
That was equivalent to just over one quarter of planned flights, dealing a blow to the sector following its recent 
strong recovery from the Covid shutdown.
The boss of Ryanair, Michael O'Leary, said the no-frills carrier had to cancel about 250 flights, affecting some 
40,000 passengers.
"Last night (Monday) we had 20 aircraft that couldn't get back to their home bases so they're out of place for today," 
he said from Dublin.
"Today, unfortunately, it looks like we're going to cancel about another 70 flights," he added, hoping that the 
situation would return to normal by Wednesday.
At Heathrow, passengers voiced frustration at the delays, which also saw planes diverted, adding hours to journey 
times.
George McHugh returned from a weekend wedding in Spain on Tuesday morning but his friends were still stuck in 
Madrid after being due to fly back on Monday.
"Once they got to the airport it was absolute chaos, everything was cancelled," he told AFP. "So we were stuck up 
in hotels and things like that.
"I'm probably just lucky that I got there this morning instead of yesterday when it all happened," he added.
On social media, angry passengers said airlines could have done better in providing support and communicating 
with passengers.
Rory Boland, travel editor at consumer advice publication Which?, said carriers were obliged to offer "timely 
rerouting" or provide overnight accommodation.
Notes

UK government orders review into air traffic control chaos
UK government orders review into air traffic control chaos
Alliance News UK
August 29, 2023 Tuesday 12:44 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Alliance News Limited All Rights Reserved
Length: 434 words
Body
(Alliance News) - The UK government on Tuesday ordered a review after the country's air traffic control system 
suffered its worst disruption in almost ten years, stranding thousands of passengers.  
Flights departing and arriving in the UK continued to be cancelled one day after air traffic control systems were 
temporarily hit by a technical fault.
Transport Secretary Mark Harper said there would be an independent review into the worst incident of its kind for 
"nearly a decade" and that is expected to last well into the week.
"This was a technical fault. We do not think this was a cybersecurity incident," he told GB News.
The last Monday of August, a public holiday in Britain, traditionally sees large numbers of passengers returning 
from summer vacations.
"I know people will be enormously frustrated by the disruption that's impacting them," Prime Minister Rishi Sunak 
said in a broadcast statement.
"Thankfully things like this are rare and the issue itself was fixed in a matter of hours, but the disruption obviously is 
continuing and will last for a little while longer."
The National Air Traffic Services said it "identified and remedied" a technical issue which forced it to impose traffic 
flow restrictions.
NATS said the issue meant flight plans had to be processed manually, while it indicated to AFP that hundreds of 
flights had been affected and that it would take "several days" for the situation to return to normal.
London's main airports continued to be affected with Heathrow and Gatwick cancelling dozens of flights Tuesday.
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA's British Airways was the worst affected airline.
UK government orders review into air traffic control chaos
Aviation analytics company Cirium said 790 departures and 785 arrivals were cancelled across all UK airports on 
Monday.
That was equivalent to just over one quarter of planned flights, dealing a blow to the sector following its recent 
strong recovery from the Covid shutdown. 
"We expect some flight cancellations and considerable flight delays today caused by this latest, still unexplained, 
NATS failure," no-frills carrier Ryanair said in a statement Tuesday.
Angry passengers took to social media, demanding a far better response from airlines. 
"Already we're seeing worrying reports of passengers being left stranded without support, and airlines failing to 
properly communicate with their passengers or fulfil their legal obligations," said Rory Boland, travel editor at 
consumer-advice publication Which?
He noted that carriers were obliged to offer "timely rerouting" or provide overnight accommodation.
source: AFP
Copyright 2023 Alliance News Ltd. All Rights Reserved.
Load-Date: August 29, 2023
End of Document
Travellers braced for more delays after air traffic fault brings holiday turmoil; Systems failure grounds planes 
Knock-on effect from flight disruption Carriers....
Travellers braced for more delays after air traffic fault brings holiday turmoil; 
Systems failure grounds planes Knock-on effect from flight disruption 
Carriers race to reschedule
Financial Times (London, England)
August 29, 2023 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2023 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; FRONT PAGE; Pg. 1
Length: 558 words
Byline: DANIEL THOMAS; JIM PICKARD
Body
Thousands of airline passengers faced long delays and flight cancellations at the end of the busy summer bank 
holiday weekend after a failure in the UK's air traffic control system yesterday grounded hundreds of aircraft.
National Air Traffic Services said it had identified and remedied a "technical issue" that had hit its capacity to 
process flight plans automatically, but the knock-on effects were set to cause continued disruption to services as 
airlines and airports scrambled to reorganise flights this week.
The problem severely restricted the number of aircraft allowed to land and take off as Nats was forced to input flight 
plans manually during the outage.
The chaos came on one of the busiest days of the year, with holidaymakers returning on the final day of the bank 
holiday weekend, days before the new school year begins.
Thousands of delayed passengers were faced with hours stuck in crowded departure halls, including families with 
children unable to return home, some having to rebook for another day. Others were trapped on planes on the 
tarmac awaiting further information on whether their flights would take off.
The delays unleashed a torrent of frustrated posts on social media from stranded travellers.
Travellers braced for more delays after air traffic fault brings holiday turmoil; Systems failure grounds planes 
Knock-on effect from flight disruption Carriers....
Chris McLaughlin, the former cochair of the UK Spaceflight Safety and Regulatory Council, wrote: "Bank Holiday 
Monday and where better to be than the BA Lounge at Heathrow. Air Traffic Failure over UK and my flight pushed 
to late afternoon - maybe."
John Strickland, an aviation analyst, said "hundreds of thousands" of passengers were affected. He said that the 
disruption was likely to spill into the next few days as airlines rearranged their planes and flight crews.
"It's an enormous problem, given the complexity on what should be a gold mine period for UK airlines," he added, 
warning of the financial impact on airlines of having to rebook passengers and reorganise schedules.
British Airways said it had been "severely disrupted" and warned that it would have to make "significant changes" to 
its schedule. It said passengers on short-haul services should check the status of their flights.
Ryanair warned that the problems were affecting "all airlines operating to and from the UK today" and said it would 
be forced to delay or cancel "a number of flights" as a result.
The system failure was one of the worst problems to hit Nats in recent years, which have included computer 
glitches and radar display problems. Nats said it would work closely with airlines and airports to manage the flights 
as efficiently as possible. "Our engineers will be carefully monitoring the system's performance as we return to 
normal operations," it added.
While the system failure affected all flights into and out of British airports, Nats said, UK airspace had remained 
open throughout.
Data provider Cirium said 232 flights had been cancelled departing UK airports as of yesterday afternoon, 
equivalent to around 8 per cent of all departures. It said that it had identified 271 arriving flights that had also been 
cancelled. But it warned there were many more aircraft that had been delayed.
Eurocontrol, the organisation that oversees air traffic management for Europe, said the failure related to the UK's 
"flight data processing system".
'It's an enormous problem, given the complexity on what should be a gold mine period for UK airlines'
Load-Date: August 28, 2023
End of Document
UK airlines and airports react to NATS technical issue
UK airlines and airports react to NATS technical issue
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
August 29, 2023 Tuesday 4:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND; Automotive, Transport and Logistics
Length: 488 words
Highlight: Airlines and airports from across the UK have been seeking to calm passengers and the wider aviation 
industry after a technical issue hit the country's air traffic control systems over a bank holiday this week.
Body
While the issue has been resolved by NATS and flights should be returning to normal levels, many passengers are 
likely to continue experiencing delays and cancellations as airlines attempt to bring their staff and aircraft back in 
line with schedules.  A spokesperson for Heathrow Airport said: "Schedules continue to be affected by yesterday's 
restrictions on UK airspace. While the majority of passengers will still be able to travel, there will unfortunately be 
some disruption on some routes, including flight cancellations." Manchester Airport also echoed similar sentiments 
and said: "There is obviously a backlog from yesterday to work through. 
Were it not for that, it would be business as usual, but because of that, it's obviously going to be a very busy day for 
our airlines and we expect there to be some delays and cancellations."  Gatwick, Edinburgh and Belfast 
International Airports also said that they were planning on running to a normal schedule but that passengers should 
still check with their airlines about possible changes to their flights.  On the airline side, Ryanair said it was trying to 
get its operations back on schedule after over 20 aircraft could not return to their home bases and expected some 
continued disruption as a result.  The airline's CEO Michael O'Leary also released a video statement to say that 
Ryanair had had to cancel about 250 flights due to the traffic restrictions on Monday, affecting 40,000 passengers 
and would be cancelling another 70 on August 29. He said that the airline was hoping to be running as normal by 
August 30, adding: "We're looking to run a couple of additional flights today, rescue flights, but it's very difficult 
because we're tight on crews, we're also tight on aircraft." The outspoken CEO also criticised NATS for not telling 
the airline what had happened and for not having backup systems, saying: "It's not acceptable that UK NATS simply 
allow their computer systems to be taken down and everybody's flights get cancelled or delayed." 
https://twitter.com/Ryanair/status/1696480035773849642?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr
%5Etweet Jet2.com also said that it would be adding extra flights to its schedule but expected more delays, with an 
update from the airline saying: "We would of course like to apologise to everyone that is affected by this situation, 
which is unfortunately completely outside of our control and await the outcome of the CAA National Air Traffic 
Services investigation into what happened."  British Airways expressed similar concerns about continuing knock-on 
UK airlines and airports react to NATS technical issue
effects but clarified that it is offering customers on short-haul services the opportunity to move flights to a later date 
for free. Meanwhile, Virgin Atlantic did not experience mass cancellations; the airline said that its VS231 and VS232 
flights from Heathrow to Austin and back were cancelled but had experienced delays and said more were still likely.
Load-Date: September 3, 2023
End of Document
UK orders independent review into air traffic control chaos
UK orders independent review into air traffic control chaos
Newstex Blogs 
Deutsche Welle World
August 29, 2023 Tuesday 2:31 PM EST

Length: 320 words
Body
August 29th, 2023 ( Deutsche Welle World  — Delivered by  Newstex )
An air traffic control glitch that left thousands of passengers stranded has caused knock-on effects that are set to 
last for days. The government on Tuesday vowed to investigate the "rare" incident.The British government has 
ordered a review into the country's air traffic control system on Tuesday after a glitch stranded thousands of 
passengers and caused delays that are set to last for days.More than 1,500 flights were cancelled on Monday, 
which was a public holiday and one of the year's busiest travel dates as school holidays draw to a close.Transport 
Secretary Mark Harper said the incident was the worst of its kind for nearly a decade and ordered an independent 
review.This was a technical fault, he told GB News. We do not think this was a cybersecurity incident.Delays for 
daysAlthough the system was brought back online within hours, the United Kingdom's National Air Traffic Services 
said the backlog of flights would last for several days.That's because airline schedules have been disrupted, and 
many flight crews are still out of place.I know people will be enormously frustrated by the disruption that's impacting 
them, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said in a broadcast statement.Thankfully things like this are rare and the issue 
itself was fixed in a matter of hours, but the disruption obviously is continuing and will last for a little while 
longer.Airlines battle travel chaosBritish Airways was the worst-affected airline.It said it was working to get back on 
track and offered short-haul passengers the option to change their flight dates for free.Meanwhile, budget carrier 
Ryanair said on Tuesday that it expected considerable flight delays plus some further flight cancellations.The UK's 
busiest airport, London Heathrow, told passengers to contact their airline before travelling to the airport on 
Tuesday.zc/lo (AFP, Reuters)

told British broadcasters.
"Thankfully things like this are rare and the issue itself was fixed in a matter of hours, but the disruption obviously is 
continuing and will last for a little while longer."

Monday.
That was equivalent to just over one quarter of planned flights, dealing a blow to the sector following its recent 
strong recovery from the Covid shutdown.
The boss of Ryanair, Michael O'Leary, said the no-frills carrier had to cancel about 250 flights, affecting some 
40,000 passengers.
"Last night (Monday) we had 20 aircraft that couldn't get back to their home bases so they're out of place for today," 
he said from Dublin.
"Today, unfortunately, it looks like we're going to cancel about another 70 flights," he added, hoping that the 
situation would return to normal by Wednesday.
At Heathrow, passengers voiced frustration at the delays, which also saw planes diverted, adding hours to journey 
times.
George McHugh returned from a weekend wedding in Spain on Tuesday morning but his friends were still stuck in 
Madrid after being due to fly back on Monday.
"Once they got to the airport it was absolute chaos, everything was cancelled," he told AFP. "So we were stuck up 
in hotels and things like that.
"I'm probably just lucky that I got there this morning instead of yesterday when it all happened," he added.
On social media, angry passengers said airlines could have done better in providing support and communicating 
with passengers.
Rory Boland, travel editor at consumer advice publication Which?, said carriers were obliged to offer "timely 
rerouting" or provide overnight accommodation.
Notes
